citation.article-title: Silvimonas iriomotensis sp. nov. and Silvimonas amylolytica sp. nov., new members of the class Betaproteobacteria isolated from the subtropical zone in Japan
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Silvimonas amylolytica sp. nov.
Silvimonas amylolytica (am.y.lo.ly′ti.ca. Gr. n. amulon starch; Gr. fem. adj. lutikê able to loosen, able to dissolve; N.L. fem. adj. amylolytica starch dissolving).
Cells are Gram-stain-negative, facultatively anaerobic, motile rods that are 0.8–1.3 μm long and 0.4–0.5 μm wide.
Growth is detected at 5–40 °C with an optimum at 30 °C.
pH range for growth is 4–9 with an optimum at pH 4.0.
Tolerates 0–1 % NaCl with optimum growth at 0 %.
Alginic acid, casein, aesculin, starch, Tween 80 and tyrosine are degraded, but agar, cellulose, chitin, gelatin, inulin, CM-cellulose, DNA and yeast cells are not.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite but not reduced to gas.
Sodium nitrate and urea are used as sole nitrogen sources for growth, but ammonium sulfate is not.

Positive metabolic activities with carbon sources of the Biolog GN2 microplate for lactulose, l-rhamnose and d,l-lactic acid and weakly positive activity for d-glucosaminic acid, but not l-asparagine, l-aspartic acid, thymidine or glucose 1-phosphate.
Major fatty acids are C14 : 0, C16 : 0, C16 : 1ω7c and C18 : 1ω7c.
DNA G+C content of the type strain is 57.5 %.
The type strain, ir6-4T (=NBRC 103189T =CGMCC 1.8860T =KCTC 22514T), was isolated from soil of the rhizosphere of bamboos collected in Iriomote Island, Japan, in 2006.
